Bachirou M., age 25, is unmarried and without children. He's a shirt reseller in Atakpamé, a city located approximately 150 kilometers from Lomé, the capital of Togo. He's been running this business for 3 years, and the results are convincing. His business consists in purchasing shirts from wholesalers, in order to retail them. With this loan, he hopes to also deliver wholesale. This will enable him to make more money, in order to improve his living conditions.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and resell bales of shirts

loans.name: Lekman

texts.en:
Lekman is a 53-year-old man who lives in Bourj El Barajneh, in the southern suburbs of Lebanon, with his wife and their three children. Lekman has been selling clothes out of his house for seven years. He also works at sewing. Lekman requested a loan of 500 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase cloth and thread for his work. Lekman has been a micro-credit client for five years now and has always paid on time.

His previous loans helped him improve his work as well as his financial situation. His clients can be anybody. When he first started his business, he had health problems. Lekman decided on doing his business because of his financial need. In the future, he plans on purchasing a shop.

loans.use: to purchase cloth and thread for his work

loans.name: Savri

texts.ru: Зокирова  Саври  женщина 51 года , швея женских  кофт и шапочек. Она использует займ для производства своей продукции. Она  связав кофты продаёт их в магазины , которые перепродают с наценкой. У неё очень красивые кофты. Саври с 2006 года заёмщица в фонде. Следующий кредит хочет использовать для закупа нитей и краски для крашения товара.Она благодарна инвесторам KIVA за понимание и финансирование .
texts.en:
Savri Z., is a 51 year old seamstress who makes women's blouses and hats. She will use her loan to produce her goods. She sews blouses and sells them in stores that marks them up and sells them off. Her blouses are very beautiful. Since 2006, Savri has been taking out loans; with this loan, she hopes to buy yarns and dyes to color her products.

Translated from Russian by Josh Machleder, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Sewing blouses

loans.name: Awaou

texts.fr:
D. Awaou est âgée de 53 ans. Awaou est originaire d'AGBATO un quartier populaire de la ville de COTONOU, Capitale Économique du Bénin. Awaou est mariée à LATIFOU Déen, un pêcheur. Awaou a trois enfants dont deux garçons et une fille tous majeurs. Awaou vendait de façon ambulante les crevettes que son mari ramenait de la pêche. Mais, vue son âge avancé, Awaou a changé d'activité. Awaou vend maintenant à domicile les condiments pour la sauce(tomate fraîche et en boîte, piment, oignon, épices, sel, gombo, crincrin, légumes, huile de palme et d'arachide, etc.) ainsi que les bois de chauffafe. C'est à Tokpa, grand marché international du Bénin que Awaou s'approvisionne en condiments. L'activité de Awaou a connu d'évolution grâce à trois crédits qu'elle a bénéficié de la part de ALIDé. Awaou veut pouvoir continuer de développer son activité; c'est pourquoi Awaou sollicite un quatrième crédit de ALIDé. 


 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500.
texts.en:
D. Awaou is 53 years old. She traces her roots to Agbato, a working-class district of the city of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is married to LATIFOU Déen, a fisherman. She has three children (2 boys and 1 girl, who are all of age).

From door to door, Awaou used to sell the shrimp that her husband brought back from fishing. But given her advanced age, she has switched to making sales at home. She now sells condiments (fresh and canned tomatoes, chili peppers, onions, spices, salt, okra, crincrin (mallow leaves), vegetables, palm oil, peanut oil, etc.), as well as firewood. Topka, the grand international marketplace of Benin, is where she acquires her supplies of condiments. Her business has experienced an improvement, thanks to the three loans she obtained from Alidé. She wants to be able to continue developing her business. This is why she’s requesting a fourth loan from Alidé.

Alidé means “there is always a path for the poorest” in Benin’s local language of Fon. Benin is a small West African country located next to Nigeria and has a per capita GDP of $1,500.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy condiments (tomatoes, onions, chili peppers, vegetables, salt, spices), two 25-liter drums of peanut oil and of palm oil, as well as some firewood

loans.name: Marie Claire

texts.en:
Greetings from U. Marie Claire, a 29-year-old married woman. She and her husband have two children, one who is 4 and another who is 5 months old, and 3 orphans, who are 8, 9 and 12 years old. She lives in the Byumba sector of the Gicumbi district in the northern province of Rwanda.

This entrepreneur does her business in the Gicumbi district, where she owns a small mixed-retail shop of mostly spare parts. She is able to earn $175 monthly profit from her business. Her husband does not have a fixed monthly income or salary because he is a mechanic and works accordingly. This entrepreneur is requesting her first loan worth 400000 Rwf from Vision Finance Company, a Kiva partner, which will help her to buy more spare parts. U. employs two workers in her business, which she started in 2004.

U. will reinvest the increased profits in the same business, pay school fees for her children and have more savings.

loans.use: Expand the business

loans.name: El Divino Niño Jesus Group

texts.es:
L. señora Antonia M. Gutiérrez es originaria D. un pequeño poblado “Ometepec” ubicado en el Estado D. Guerrero. Durante años se ha dedicado a trabajar como empleada domestica a  cuidar a una pequeña niña. L. señora Antonia también tiene 2 hijos pequeños los cuales ha descuidado por llevar un salario mínimo a su casa y así apoyar a su esposo en los gastos familiares.  Debido a sus necesidades inició hace tres años y D. forma ambulante L. venta D. pollo los cuales compraba y vendía, pero hoy pretenD. tener un negocio propio, en el cual no descuiD. a sus 2 hijos  y podrá darles L. mayor herencia: su educación, para que ellos puedan desempeñarse en L. sociedad como personas D. valores, útiles y capaces. Por eso solicitó un crédito  para su gran sueño una granja propia,  y eso lo hará con  L. compra D. pollos,  alimentos, comederos para L. crianza.
Es por esta razón que L. señora Antonia M. G. se ha unido con un grupo D. 13 personas, al cual pusieron como nombre del grupo “El Divino Niño J.”  para solicitar el crédito grupal a Fundación Realidad A.C.
Las otras personas del grupo son las siguientes:
Epifania L. M. - Compra y venta D. productos agrícolas
Monica D. Jesus H.  - Venta D. pescado
Margarita M. L.  - Venta D. blusas artesanales
Julio D. L. C. D. J.  - Compra y venta D. maíz
Maria H. Barragán  - Venta D. abarrotes
Victorina G. F.  - Venta D. comida en cocina económica
Silvia F. P.  - Venta D. ropa
Silvia M. M. -  Elaboración y venta D. pan
Petrona Soledad M. G. - Elaboración y venta D. pan
Erasmo F. L.  -  Elaboración y venta D. pan
Maxima H. A. – Venta D. blusas artesanales
Maria D. L. Luz E. P.  -  Venta D. ropa
texts.en:
Antonia M. Gutiérrez is from a small town called Ometepec, which is located in the state of Guerrero. She worked for several years as a domestic servant taking care of a little girl. Antonia also has two small children whom she doesn’t get to spend much time with since she has to make a minimum wage so she can help her husband with the family’s expenses. Out of necessity, three years ago she started working as a street vendor selling chicken that she bought and then sold. Now she intends to have her own business so that she can take care of her 2 children and give them a better future via education, so that they can contribute to society as good citizens who are useful and capable. This is why she has requested a loan for her big dream—her own small chicken farm. She will start it by buying chickens, feed, and feeders for the chicks. For this reason, Antonia M. G. has created a group of 13 people, who decided to use the group name “El Divino Niño J.” (The Divine Baby Jesus), to request a group loan from Fundación Realidad A.C. The other people in the group are the following: Epifania L. M. – Buying and selling of agricultural products Monica D. Jesus H. – Fish sales Margarita M. L. – Embroidered blouse sales Julio D. L. C. D. J. – Buying and selling of corn Maria H. Barragán – Grocery sales Victorina G. F. – Food sales in a home café Silvia F. P. – Clothing sales Silvia M. M. – Bread production and sales Petrona Soledad M. G. - Bread production and sales Erasmo F. L. - Bread production and sales Maxima H. A. – Embroidered blouse sales Maria D. L. Luz E. P. – Clothing sales

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She will buy materials to construct a small farm for raising chickens

loans.name: Stephen Kyalo

texts.en:
Stephen M. is a 28-year-old married father of one. He has a business making and selling sofas, chairs, beds and other furniture. This will be his first loan from KADET, and it is the first time he has borrowed money to fund his business.

Stephen's business is five years old and a success. He now has three locations employing three full-time workers. His employees frame, fill and upholster the furniture he sells. With this 50,000 Kenyan shilling loan, Stephen plans to buy upholstery fabric, filling material such as foam and fabric scraps, wood to make sofa frames, and to pay employee wages.

In the future, Stephen hopes to own a first-class furniture shop and open a storefront in Mombasa's central business district.

About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions.

loans.use: To buy furniture-making materials and to pay employee wages.

loans.name: Luisita

texts.en:
Luisita O. is from the village of Poblacion, Mahinog Camiguin. She is 45 years old. Luisita is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Luisita owns & operates a variety store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of daily use products in the local community. Luisita has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Luisita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Luisita is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Luisita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Fatma

texts.en:
Fatma is a member of the Tuwepamoja borrower group. She is 31 years old, married, and a mother of 7 children. Her children are aged 15, 13, 10, 8, 6, 4, and 1 years.

Fatma started her own business selling charcoal 2 years ago. She works 8 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 120,000.

This is Fatma's first loan from BRAC. She requested the amount of 300,000 in order to buy more charcoal for sale. With the profit she makes from the use of this loan, Fatma hopes to save money and expand her business

loans.use: to buy more charcoal

loans.name: Rita

texts.en:
Rita is 56 years old and is the mother of three children, ranging in age from 15 to 20 years old. Her eldest child and youngest decided not to continue their studies toward college, one after high school and the other after elementary school. Rita's last hope is with her second child, who is now in her second year of college. Rita tries her best to grow her business in order to finance her child's college education. Rita's husband is her assistant in running her own business. 

When Rita joined ASHI in 2004, she had a loan to start up a business and was able to raise pigs. After raising several pigs and selling them, she has been able to start a general store that she is expanding. She wants to fill up her store with commodities needed by people in their village. The loan she requests now will be used to purchase canned foods, beverages, and rice. 

In the years to come, Rita wishes to have more loans to be able to expand her general store into a mini grocery store that sells a lot of things people need every day of their lives. She hopes to stabilize her business for her two children to take over since they are college undergraduates.

loans.use: To purchase goods

loans.name: Odet

texts.pt:
Odete Antonio M. nasceu no distrito de boane, tem 27 anos de idade, solteira e mãe de 2 filhos com 3 e 9 anos de idade, a mais velha estuda na escola publica de boane. Odete estudou ate 6 classe e parou cedo para ir ao lar. Actualmente separada vive somente com os filhos na casa própria e sem ninguém sob sua responsabilidade.

Cresceu na companhia dos seus pais, no mesmo distrito de Boane, e nunca mudou de residência. Tem saído para áfrica de sul para visitar familiares.
Vende roupa usada para todas as idades há mais de 10 anos em frente ao mercado da vila de boane. Compra cada fardo a 5.100,00MT, revende a 7.500,00MT ganhando 2.000,00MT no final de cada mês. as vezes vende um fardo e meio.

Já teve empréstimos em outras instituições similares para o exercício da mesma actividade e tendo pagado sem problemas. Teve informações sobre a Hluvuku-Adsema através de vizinhas clientes da instituição.

Este vai ser o terceiro empréstimo da Odete com a instituição no valor de 13.000,00MT para compra de fardos de roupa usada. Espera reembolsar sem problemas para poder aceder a mais créditos com objectivo de construir um estabelecimento de alvenaria, para melhor vender os seus produtos e ganhar mais clientes.
texts.en:
Odete Antonio M. was born in the district of Boane. She is 27 years old, single, and the mother of 2 children ages 3 and 9. The oldest goes to the Boane Public School. Odete went to school through the 6th grade and stopped early to be in the home. She is recently separated and lives alone with her children in her own home. She does not care for anyone else. She grew up with her parents in the same district of Boane, and she never moved. However, she has gone to South Africa to visit family. She has been selling used clothing for all ages for more than 10 years in front of the market in the town of Boane. She buys each bundle for 5,100MT and sells them for 7,500MT earning her 2,000MT at the end of each month. Sometimes she sells a bundle and a half. She has received other loans from similar institutions and paid them off without problems. She got information about Hluvuku-Adsema through neighbors who are clients. This will be her third loan with Hluvuku in the amount of 13,000MT to purchase bundles of used clothing. She hopes to pay off the loan without issue so she can apply for more credit with the objective of constructing an brick establishment to improve the sales of her products and gain more customers.

Translated from Portuguese by Jared Wandry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy and Sell used clothing (all ages)

loans.name: Librada

texts.en:
Librada O. is from the village of Gumbil,Tudela,Misamis Occidental. He is 39 years old. Librada is married and has 1 school-aged children. To make a living, Librada owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. Librada has been engaged in his business for over 4 years and earns approximately 2,000.00 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Librada joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Librada has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000.00 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future. Librada is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Librada from PMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Rose Mary

texts.en: Rosemary is 33 year married with five children aged between 6 and 14. All her children go to school .She resides and rents a two roomed house where she stays with seven people  Rosemary doesn’t take care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity and no piped water.   Rosemary works in semi urban area which in the outskirts of Kampala.  She is a tailor on Lubaga Road and buys clothing materials from Owino market and so she pays for transport costs to and from shopping.  She doesn’t pay rent for her business but as she works from her home. Rosemary sells to all categories of people both on retail and whole sale and works six days a week Rosemary before joining the sewing\tailoring business; she was dealing in locally made cold drinks. She has been in this business for nine years and with MCDT for six years servicing her twelfth loan, working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more clothing materials. She is aspiring of seeing her business grow bigger and owning fashion and designing shop

loans.use: to buy more clothing materials

loans.name: Leila

texts.en:
Leila L., 42, is a farmer from Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. She owns 1-hectare rice field and runs rice farming business. She's a mother of three children. Her eldest is 21 years old. She sends her children to school out from the income she receives from her farm.

She's now requesting a loan from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. worth 15,000 PHP. This is very helpful for her to buy supplies necessary for her farm. She will be able to save her financing from CEVI instead of lending money from rice trader which has a high interest.

loans.use: Financing
